lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
In React, props allow you to pass data from one component to another.

We often use props to share functions between components, too.

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Passing a function through properties to a child component works similarly to passing variables that hold values.

We can access the passed function by name and use it as we wish. For example, we can call it at the click of a button.

Make sure to pick props followed by props and then ., greet.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
In the parent component, we pass a defined function like we pass any other variable.

When using ES6 syntax to define a function, we can assign it to a variable and pass it to another component to use.

Make sure to pick logGreeting, followed by greet, and finally logGreeting.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
We're not restricted to using functions without parameters. We can define functions that accept one or multiple parameters as well.

Make sure to pick (color).

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can use the passed value to change the state of the parent component, which will allow it to keep track of the selection.

While the child component takes care of the UI and doesn't care about state management.

Make sure to pick setSelectedColor, followed by color, and finally selectedColor.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
In the child component, we pass the selected color on click. We achieve this by using map to create a button per item in the colors array.

Each rendered button gets its own function with a unique parameter based on the item in the array.

Make sure to pick color followed by props and then .onColorSelect, color.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
To make the function call on the button click and not on render, we need to wrap the passed function inside an arrow function.

If we don't do that, the function will be executed on render.

Make sure to pick (), followed by =>, and finally props.onColorSelect(color).

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can use the state variable as we want in the parent component. We don't care about the child's UI.

This ensures separation of concerns: the parent is unaffected by the child's changes as long as the child uses the provided function.

Make sure to pick selectedColor followed by setSelectedColor and then setSelectedColor, selectedColor.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
Pass a function that logs a favorite show from Parent to Child and call it when the button is clicked.

Make sure to pick logFavoriteShow followed by showLog and then =, {, logFavoriteShow, }.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
What will be displayed in the console when the button is clicked?

Message from parentNothing will be displayedAn error will occurClick me

Message from parent.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
Demonstrate using a method that changes the parent's state from the child component.

Make sure to pick props, followed by props, and finally .sendMessage.

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
What will happen if the button is clicked and 'props.sendMessage' was called directly as 'props.sendMessage('Hello from Child!')'?

The function will execute during renderAn error will occurThe button will not workNothing will happen

The function will execute during render.

lessons.title: Lesson #13
lessons.interactiveContent:
Implement a child component that increments the parent's counter value and displays the updated count by using the passed function.

Make sure to type increment.

lessons.title: Lesson #14
lessons.interactiveContent:
When should you wrap a function in an arrow function in a child component?

If you want the function call to occur on an event, not on renderIf you want the function to run only onceIf you do not expect the function to ever runIf the function has no parameters

If you want the function call to occur on an event, not on render.
